what_section:
Fighting a speeding ticket means formally disputing the charge through Calgary Traffic Court. When you receive a speeding ticket in Calgary, you have options beyond simply paying the fine.

The process involves requesting disclosure (the evidence against you), reviewing police notes and radar calibration records, and presenting your case to a prosecutor or judge.

Many Alberta drivers successfully reduce or eliminate speeding tickets through this process, especially with professional guidance from paralegal services like Fabsy.
how_section:
Step 1: Request disclosure from Calgary Traffic Court within 30 days. This gets you the officer's notes, radar/laser gun calibration records, and other evidence.

Step 2: Review the disclosure carefully. Look for technical errors, calibration issues, or procedural mistakes that could invalidate the ticket.

Step 3: Attend a prosecutor review meeting or request a trial date. Most Calgary traffic tickets are resolved through prosecutor negotiation without going to trial.

Professional representatives like Fabsy handle this entire process, attend meetings on your behalf, and negotiate the best possible outcome.
next_section:
Once you've decided to fight your ticket, act quickly. You typically have 30 days from the ticket date to request disclosure and begin the process.

Gather all relevant information: your ticket number, driver's license, and any photos or notes from the incident. These details help build your defense.

Consider professional help. Fabsy's licensed paralegals specialize in Calgary traffic tickets and have relationships with local prosecutors, leading to better outcomes than self-representation.

Most importantly, don't delay. Missing deadlines means losing your right to dispute the ticket and facing the full fine and demerit points.

faqs.q: Do I need a lawyer to fight a speeding ticket in Calgary?
faqs.a: Not required, but recommended. Professional representation increases success rates by 40%. Fabsy's licensed paralegals handle Calgary traffic tickets daily and know the local courts well.

faqs.q: How long does it take to fight a speeding ticket in Calgary?
faqs.a: Most cases resolve in 2-6 weeks through prosecutor review. If a trial is needed, expect 2-6 months. Fabsy handles everything so you don't need to take time off work.

faqs.q: Will fighting my ticket increase the fine?
faqs.a: No. The fine cannot increase by disputing it. You can only maintain the current fine or reduce it through negotiation. There's no downside to fighting the ticket.

faqs.q: What happens at Calgary Traffic Court?
faqs.a: Most cases are resolved before trial through prosecutor meetings. If trial is needed, you present your case to a justice of the peace. Fabsy represents you at all meetings and hearings.

faqs.q: Can I get my speeding ticket completely dismissed in Calgary?
faqs.a: Yes, dismissals happen when there are technical errors or procedural issues. More commonly, tickets are reduced to lower fines with fewer or zero demerit points through negotiation.
